Question 1. What does "merge" mean in the context of Git?
A. To delete a file from the repository.
B. To create two simultaneous copies of the same file.
C. To incorporate independent edits of the same file into a single unified file.
D. To merge two repositories into a unified one.

Question 2. What is the purpose of "staging" in Git?
A. To prepare a file for deletion.
B. To prepare a file for a commit.
C. To download a file from the repository.
D. To prepare a file for add

Question 3. What is a repository in terms of version control?
A. The location where all the version controlled files and their changes are located.
B. The location where only the final versions of files are stored.
C. A type of software used for version control.
D. A GitHub repository and their changes are located..

Question 4. What does "pull" mean in the context of Git?
A. To delete a file from the repository.
B. To upload a file to the repository.
C. To update your local version of the repository to the current version.
D. To pull a file to the repository.

Question 5. Which of the following is true about Git?
A. Git is a paid version control system.
B. Git keeps a local copy of your work and revisions, which can be edited offline.
C. Git does not interface well with RStudio.
D. Git is a version control tool from GitHub

Question 6. What is a commit in the context of version control?
A. A commit is to save your edits and the changes made.
B. A commit is to update the repository with your edits.
C. A commit is when independent edits of the same file are incorporated into a single unified file.
D. A commit should be done after git add

Question 7. What is a fork in the context of version control?
A. A fork is when multiple people make changes to the same file and Git is unable to merge the edits.
B. A fork is when the same file has two simultaneous copies.
C. A fork is a personal copy of a repository that you have taken from another person.
D. A fork is to copy other people's code on github

Question 8. How do you link Git to RStudio?
A. In RStudio, open the File menu and choose "New Git Repository".
B. In RStudio, use the command git init in the console.
C. In RStudio,  go to Tools,  then click Git option and that will generate ".git" folder
D. In RStudio, go to Tools, then Global Options, then Git/SVN and confirm the correct directory for git.exe.

Question 9. How to clone an existing project from GitHub to RStudio?
A. Go to RStudio > New Project > Version Control > Git > Paste the repository URL > Create the project.
B. Open Terminal > Use the command git clone followed by the repository URL.
C. Go to GitHub > Click on the "Clone or download" button > Download ZIP > Unzip the project on your local machine > Open the project in RStudio.
D. Go to RStudio  > Open the project > Use git clone command

Question 10. How do you link a local project, which is not under version control, to Git and GitHub?
A. Create a new repository on GitHub > Go to RStudio and select "Version Control" under New Project > Paste the repository URL.
B. In terminal, navigate to the project directory > Initialize the directory as a Git repository using "git init" > Commit the changes > Create a new repository on GitHub with the same name > Link the local repository to GitHub using the command line.
C. In RStudio, select "New Git Repository" under the File menu > Commit the changes > Create a new repository on GitHub with the same name > Push the changes to the GitHub repository.
D. In RStudio, Use "git --config" to set Git configuration values on a global or local project level>  Initialize the directory as a Git repository using "git init"  > Create the ".git" folder >  Link the local repository to GitHub using the command line.
